commit_message:
Log VM console output in remote_connectivity_check

If remote connectivity check fails because of SSH issue or
becasuse of assertion error, console output from instances used
for test will now be logged as it is useful for debugging such
failed tests.

It is similar to what was already done in check_connectivity() method.

Change-Id: I0fb95efd09881492b8e39d5e114b42c1bd944e57

commit_message:
Return the endpoint_override from EndpointData

Setting up an Adapter with an endpoint_override, calling
get_endpoint_data() on that adapter, and accessing the `url` @property
of the resulting EndpointData now regurgitates the endpoint_override
initially set on the Adapter.

Change-Id: I1033c97a7b0e19a75fa0d3c5682cf18b75918514
Closes-Bug: #1707993

'}, {'created': '2018-05-15 07:42:34.000000000', 'message': "Raise KeyboardInterrupt on SIGTERM - Workaround

Catch SIGTERM signal and call the signal handler method.
The signal handler then raises KeyboardInterrupt. The
KeyboardInterrupt won't be caught by any 'except Exception'
clauses.

Without this the service does not stop periodic workers,
tear down pxe filters etc as it is supposed to on shutdown.

NOTE: Calling shutdown() directly from the signal handler
causes the below error. This is why the signal handler
raises KeyboardInterrupt.
 AssertionError: Cannot switch to MAINLOOP from MAINLOOP

This patch differs from the commit on master in that it
also imports 'signal' module. In master the signal module
was already imported.

Related-Bug: #1765700

(cherry picked from commit 737dbeae118cc136597565c8c1449fca4945143c)
"}]
commit_message:
Raise KeyboardInterrupt on SIGTERM - Workaround

Catch SIGTERM signal and call the signal handler method.
The signal handler then raises KeyboardInterrupt. The
KeyboardInterrupt won't be caught by any 'except Exception'
clauses.

Without this the service does not stop periodic workers,
tear down pxe filters etc as it is supposed to on shutdown.

NOTE: Calling shutdown() directly from the signal handler
causes the below error. This is why the signal handler
raises KeyboardInterrupt.
 AssertionError: Cannot switch to MAINLOOP from MAINLOOP

This patch differs from the commit on master in that it
also imports 'signal' module. In master the signal module
was already imported.

Related-Bug: #1765700

Story: 2001890
Task: 14374
Change-Id: If0e24eae767b7806243fa4ae34fedb30ae9af25a
(cherry picked from commit 737dbeae118cc136597565c8c1449fca4945143c)

commit_message:
Debug logs for allocation_candidates filters

Add debug log messages describing why we're excluding allocation
requests from GET /allocation_candidates for the following scenarios:

- When used + amount exceeds capacity (this usually happens because
  we combine more than one AllocationRequestResource).
- When amount exceeds max_unit (ditto).
- When group_policy=isolate and the allocation request has more than one
  AllocationRequestResource from the same resource provider for
  different request groups.

Change-Id: Id9ce14e3bb5df24cbbd0d6a1015fa9829f4467c2

commit_message:
Align tests with how functional tests are handled

- move tests directory under kolla_cli
- create new functional directory and put all tests in there
- add empty unit test directory
- add "test_" as a prefix to all test files (so ostestr sees them)
- use ostestr (--serial) to run the tests
- add functional tests into tox and zuul configs
- update tests/common to rip out code that selected which cli
command to use. will now always use python kolla_cli/shell.py

No test files were modified.

Change-Id: Iec80f7546b0f4ff2a857b14f546fd299732c727d
Implements: blueprint initial-testing

commit_message:
Fix functional test about port

Also updates jobs in .zuul.yaml to run stable/queens code and to not
bother running the osc functional job which doens't work and to block
the pep8 madness that happened recently.

Change-Id: Ifaef01ec5f348b7bd7466ec6c662a204d78af2d3
(cherry picked from commit 7cdb723c612cf6ed89c3d53c0b98430e2bd88f96)

This should be fine as 3.26.0 has the necessary fixes for the linked review (security fix)'}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2018-04-06 04:13:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2018-04-06 04:17:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

actually, maybe we should bump UC first?'}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2018-04-10 07:31:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-2

(2 comments)

The global-requirements change is a stable policy violation'}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2018-04-10 07:36:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2018-04-11 20:41:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

after discussing this in our meeting we would like the following.

As this is a rocky release that you are wishing to use we have to reject it.
Please backport the change needed to the queens branch and release a 3.25.1 version with the fix as a queens release.
Once that's done, make a constraints update.
Since this is a logging vuln that this fixes we do not wish to bump the effective minimum."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-04-11 20:42:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

> after discussing this in our meeting we would like the following.
 > 
 > As this is a rocky release that you are wishing to use we have to
 > reject it.
 > Please backport the change needed to the queens branch and release
 > a 3.25.1 version with the fix as a queens release.
 > Once that's done, make a constraints update.
 > Since this is a logging vuln that this fixes we do not wish to bump
 > the effective minimum.

The backport to oslo.concurrency is done (and linked in the commit message).

The release will cause the constraint update to be proposed.

The backport in cinder will need to work whether the version of oslo.concurrency has the new argument or not, so you'll need to take some care with that."}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2018-05-16 20:52:15.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

This is not a security fix, as such there is no GR bump necessary.  Also, 3.25.1 with the fix is already in queens upper-constraints.txt.'}]

commit_message:
Update G-R for oslo.concurrency>=3.26.0

The cinder project requires new parameter 'sanitize_stdout' in
method oslo_concurrency.processutils.ssh_execute that is merged
with [0] and only available in oslo.concurrency 3.26.0 or newer.

[0] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/547388/

Change-Id: I4e119c4e494b6302ca698dda467a07d91d0e0630
Closes-bug: #1482382
(cherry picked from commit 34b6e6fa97b5a779baf0aa42e9fff049734997bb)

commit_message:
Lower log level for the maintenance thread

Prior to this patch the maintenance thread was logging an warning when
any inconsistencies were found between the Neutron and OVN database
without any message saying that it's going to be fixed automatically.
That caused confusion between users.

This patch is changing the message to be less "scary" and lowering it's
log level as well because the inconsistencies are going to be fixed
without the need of any manual interaction from the administrator.

DEBUG was choosen over INFO for the message because usually INFO is
choosen to indicate that something has been completed already instead
of some on-going operation. That said, we are already logging an INFO
message at the end of the synchronization to inform that it has been
completed and how long it took.

Change-Id: I520f3f1f6bd61c2ec8d8ed29260c7ebec8f0184f

    v = v.decode('ASCII') if isinstance(v, six.binary_type) else v
UnicodeDecodeError: 'ascii' codec can't decode byte 0xc3 in position 2: ordinal not in range(128)'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2018-05-15 15:34:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Looks like https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc8187 (which obsoletes RFC 5987) specifies headers and values must be transmitted in 7-bit ASCII as defined by https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc20 (there are provisions for different charsets, etc., but that doesn't affect us here because all that stuff must be transmitted in ASCII as well).  So I think the failure i mentioned in my previous comment has to be fixed on the glance side."}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2018-05-15 20:44:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

commit_message:
Fix logging of encoded headers

A change introduced in 3.5.0 sorts headers, but runs into a problem
when the headers are bytes, such as the headers provided by the
python-glanceclient.

requests expects headers to be str type in both python2 and python3.
This means in python2 we need to encode unicode objects as ASCII (the
encoding that should be used for HTTP headers) and in python3 we need to
decode bytes as ASCII into str.

Change-Id: Ib81497c3a873616c22ba68256c596a6fb113e11e
Closes-bug: #1766235

subject: Check cirros symlink before creation
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-15 20:54:16.000000000', 'message': "Check cirros symlink before creation

Currently, run_tests.sh does:
ln -s ~/cache/files/cirros-0.4.0-x86_64-disk.img $IMG_DIR

inconditionally. This patch checks if the file exists and is a symlink
before doing the ln -s.

This helps running ./all-in-one.sh twice if the first attempt failed, for
some reasons, which isn't hypothetical, it happens often that it fails
because of networking problems (bad WIFI) on my laptop.

Change-Id: I3faed512a1eeccef15f4965d6deb2151eab9d36d
"}]
commit_message:
Check cirros symlink before creation

Currently, run_tests.sh does:
ln -s ~/cache/files/cirros-0.4.0-x86_64-disk.img $IMG_DIR

inconditionally. This patch checks if the file exists and is a symlink
before doing the ln -s.

This helps running ./all-in-one.sh twice if the first attempt failed, for
some reasons, which isn't hypothetical, it happens often that it fails
because of networking problems (bad WIFI) on my laptop.

Change-Id: I3faed512a1eeccef15f4965d6deb2151eab9d36d

unit tests working now, gotta get back to the func test'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2018-05-03 16:28:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2018-05-03 16:39:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 8770, 'date': '2018-05-04 18:25:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Dan this looks great.  Once this lands I'll add support for the remaining drivers.

One subjective suggestion - after hacking around with this patch I felt that the term "heartbeat" has become overloaded in the rabbit code base.  Prior to this patch we had lots of rabbit code and options using the generic term 'heartbeat' for connection monitoring.  Using the term 'heartbeat' to also refer to RPC timeout handling makes the codebase a little ambiguous.  Just IMHO.

I've got no problems using the term heartbeat for the client API parameters.  I'm really just inferring to the internal codebase's use of 'heartbeat'.

What do you think of a follow on patch with something a little more specific to this feature, like rpc_keepalive or similar for naming methods/attributes?'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2018-05-07 14:10:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

> Dan this looks great.  Once this lands I'll add support for the
 > remaining drivers.
 > 
 > One subjective suggestion - after hacking around with this patch I
 > felt that the term "heartbeat" has become overloaded in the rabbit
 > code base.  Prior to this patch we had lots of rabbit code and
 > options using the generic term 'heartbeat' for connection
 > monitoring.  Using the term 'heartbeat' to also refer to RPC
 > timeout handling makes the codebase a little ambiguous.  Just IMHO.
 > 
 > I've got no problems using the term heartbeat for the client API
 > parameters.  I'm really just inferring to the internal codebase's
 > use of 'heartbeat'.
 > 
 > What do you think of a follow on patch with something a little more
 > specific to this feature, like rpc_keepalive or similar for naming
 > methods/attributes?

That's fine with me. I'm happy to rework this patch to use a different name, and I'm also happy to have it exposed via the api with that name. Not sure what that should be though. More word brainstorming:

"Call signaling"
"Call monitoring"
"Active calls"
"Live call monitoring"

Anyway, you pick and I'll rename :)'}, {'account_id': 8770, 'date': '2018-05-08 15:26:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

"call monitoring" +1'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2018-05-08 15:59:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Workflow-1

the server. This enables the user to increase the regular timeout to
a much larger value, allowing calls to take a very long time, but

commit_message:
[rabbitmq] Implement active call monitoring

This adds an optional call_monitor_timeout parameter to the RPC client,
which if specified, will enable heartbeating of long-running calls by
the server. This enables the user to increase the regular timeout to
a much larger value, allowing calls to take a very long time, but
with heartbeating to indicate that they are still running on the server
side. If the server stops heartbeating, then the call_monitor_timeout
takes over and we fail with the usual MessagingTimeout instead of waiting
for the longer overall timeout to expire.

Change-Id: I60334aaf019f177a984583528b71d00859d31f84

commit_message:
Update PCI passthrough template for >= Pike

The [pci] header is necessary since pike [0]. This change updates the
pike template to add the [pci] header, rename pci_passthrough_whitelist
to passthrough_whitelist and add the config option pci-alias.

[0] https://docs.openstack.org/nova/pike/admin/pci-passthrough.html

Change-Id: I7a8c76f5989edb5b4a0b30036ce722ffb0ecb7ab

Okay, that seems worth a procedural hold.'}, {'account_id': 23498, 'date': '2018-04-25 23:05:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 20:

so we should be good to go with the driver functionality being exercised in the CI.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-05-09 20:15:44.000000000', 'content': 'Removed Code-Review-2 by Eric Fried <efried@us.ibm.com>

commit_message:
PowerVM Driver: Snapshot

Add instance snapshot support for the PowerVM virt driver.

Blueprint: powervm-snapshot

Change-Id: I2691b09d95691915dc1065284d25ad22db41d32b

it works.

commit_message:
Ensure neutron-server works after starting

In Debian, running neutron net-list after starting neutron-server fails
because it takes too much time for neutron-server to be up. Even using
Type=notify in the .service unit doesn't help.

So this patch uses openstacklib::service_validation to run
openstack network list after the server is started, to make sure
it works.

commit_message:
Re-enable rename container test

This test was disabled because the API endpoint of rename was
removed and re-introduced by the 'patch' endpoint. The change
is finished so this patch re-enable the test with the new
API endpoint.

Change-Id: I1789822e34452ba90bfb15eb91e34aa262dd0f88

commit_message:
Run containers update only for required packages

Run containers update only for packages which were built and their
dependencies. Don't run container update at all if nothing was
built in the patch.

Depends on https://github.com/imain/container-check/pull/2 to pass
Change-Id: I764bc9a368e63a9aa82ec5503bcd3a9c7c6f4e25

commit_message:
FFU Set NetworkDeploymentActions CREATE,UPDATE for ffwd-upgrade prepare

And unset back to CREATE on ffwd-upgrade converge. See [0] for more
discussion. This is to allow operators to update to the new script
based os-net-config network templates during the ffwd-upgrade.

[0] https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1568561#c3

commit_message:
New Airship project - Diving Bell

Airship is a collection of components that provide a declarative
interface for deploying a bare metal Kubernetes cluster at scale to
facilitate integrated deployment of OpenStack on Kubernetes using the
existing OpenStack-Helm project [1].

Diving Bell is a lightweight host configuration management tool.  It
fits in the Airship ecosystem in areas where leveraging containers for
configuration management is not ideal.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/openstack-helm

Change-Id: I7728db62cfa2400808307958fc9e7e061ae2a04d

commit_message:
Bump OpenStack service version

* Bump cinder from 12.0.0 to 12.0.1
* Bump glance from 16.0.0 to 16.0.1
* Bump heat from 10.0.0 to 10.0.1
* Bump horizon from 13.0.0 to 13.0.1
* Bump manila from 6.0.0 to 6.0.1
* Bump mistral from 6.0.1 to 6.0.2
* Bump networking-ovn from 4.0.0 to 4.0.1
* Bump neutron-dynamic-routing from 12.0.0 to 12.0.1
* Bump neutron from 12.0.1 to 12.0.2
* Bump nova from 17.0.2 to 17.0.3
* Bump panko from 4.0.0 to 4.0.1
* Bump zaqar from 6.0.0 to 6.0.1
* Bump zaqar-ui from 4.0.0 to 4.0.1

Change-Id: Ica8b88dba62635367ed1abeb57fee91ed0271cb5

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-15 08:33:35.000000000', 'message': 'Remove install-requirements script

this script is not used anywhere anymore, and it will not work
with recent pip 10.x release due to changes in the pip API.

Initially this script was meant to install only a limited set of requirements
to run heat_integrationtests without having to install whole Heat.

Since the split of heat_tempest_plugin the tests left in the
heat_integrationtests are meant to be run only in a DevStack-like env,
so all the requirements are already available.

Change-Id: I94c82fe100dfb6557cc960ef1198f1195780f28f
'}]
commit_message:
Remove install-requirements script

this script is not used anywhere anymore, and it will not work
with recent pip 10.x release due to changes in the pip API.

Initially this script was meant to install only a limited set of requirements
to run heat_integrationtests without having to install whole Heat.

Since the split of heat_tempest_plugin the tests left in the
heat_integrationtests are meant to be run only in a DevStack-like env,
so all the requirements are already available.

Change-Id: I94c82fe100dfb6557cc960ef1198f1195780f28f

commit_message:
Correct error handling in early deployment state

First, after move to openstacksdk get_image_info/get_network raise
an exception instead of returning None. Second, we need to clean up
reservation and ports when it happens.

Change-Id: Iecb97aaf41d226efeb8163ac6cd20ade101a742f

Make Neutron integration job voting

Neutron has updated the neutron-tempest-plugin-designate-scenario job to
be voting [0], let's follow that path.

[0] https://review.openstack.org/568681

Change-Id: Ifdfbdb4d465bc70b02be1c3f049dbfac67de4c88

commit_message:
quota: Move targets argument to get_disabled_quotas

In addition, unnecessary API calls determined by 'targets'
are now removed.

blueprint make-quotas-great-again
Change-Id: I77b1335c25f2e2f3952e0d3c59f8c89a2bad3195

commit_message:
Delete sandbox on capsule delete

We need to delete the sandbox for cleaning up the networking
resources. Otherwise, the neutron ports of the capsule won't
be cleaned up.

Closes-Bug: #1762895
Change-Id: I798d32d04b679b4c3cfb48adbc21dade102b8ce3

commit_message:
Revert "Create floating ip by normal user"

I think these initial load balancer patches went in the wrong direction and are not aligned to the modern tempest documentation/path. I think we need to restore Jude's work.

This reverts commit bf966a9b2553adc6a74b0b3c99acb243f3676201.

Change-Id: I28c9723d55875542a38c115d03f3d1555406209d

use FQDNs for the SubjectAltName, and that will be verified.
This required for us to change both CloudDomain and CloudName to be

avoid folks in real deployments using them in their clouds.

commit_message:
Switch public endpoints to use FQDNs by default

This is in preparation for TLS by default, since the TLS certificate will
use FQDNs for the SubjectAltName, and that will be verified.
This required for us to change both CloudDomain and CloudName to be
required parameters, and not default them to use localdomain. This is to
avoid folks in real deployments using them in their clouds.

Change-Id: Ic70dd323b33596eaa3fc18bdc69a7c011ccd7fa1

commit_message:
quota: Merge tenant_limit_usages into tenant_quota_usages

The response of tenant_quota_usages is now baesd on the limit API,
so tenant_limit_usages and tenant_quota_usages provide same information.
This commit changes all consumers of tenant_limit_usages to use
tenant_quota_usages and updates the corresponding templates.

blueprint make-quotas-great-again
Change-Id: I620e2946f2aca31bac134c247ceaf971498f9eeb

commit_message:
Add conceptual overview of the service catalog

During the Liberty summit in Vancouver, there was a session on
the standardization of the service catalog:

  https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/service-catalog-cross-project-vancouver

As a result, Dolph put together a really good post condensing that
information for client developers as well as developers working
on integrating their services into the OpenStack ecosystem:

  https://blog.dolphm.com/openstack-keystone-service-catalog/

This commit massages some of the wording and proposes the guide as a
section of our own contributor documentation.

Co-Authored-By: Lance Bragstad <lbragstad@gmail.com>

Change-Id: Ie3328a8f7e093e894903a48809761fcbad279154
Closes-Bug: 1459402

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-08 00:02:39.000000000', 'message': 'Read in ca certificate as binary for PY3

The comparison of bytes vs string of the CA certificate produces a
false negative. This leads to rewriting certificates and affecting
connectivity to services. The writing of the file was changed to bytes
in https://github.com/juju/charm-helpers/pull/58/.

Read in the certificate as bytes as well for a bytes vs bytes
comparison.

Change-Id: I64eb2b90776bb1e37de009208f016f176bd6a82a
Closes-Bug: #1762431
'}, {'created': '2018-05-09 20:42:17.000000000', 'message': 'Read in ca certificate as binary for PY3

The comparison of bytes vs string of the CA certificate produces a
false negative. This leads to rewriting certificates and affecting
connectivity to services. The writing of the file was changed to bytes
in https://github.com/juju/charm-helpers/pull/58/.

Read in the certificate as bytes as well for a bytes vs bytes
comparison.

Adding some code around to retry keystone_wait_for_propagation() for 30
secs if api_version attribute is missing (just for testing at the
moment, as this CI job is hitting on the issue consistently)

Change-Id: I64eb2b90776bb1e37de009208f016f176bd6a82a

commit_message:
Read in ca certificate as binary for PY3

The comparison of bytes vs string of the CA certificate produces a
false negative. This leads to rewriting certificates and affecting
connectivity to services. The writing of the file was changed to bytes
in https://github.com/juju/charm-helpers/pull/58/.

Read in the certificate as bytes as well for a bytes vs bytes
comparison.

Change-Id: I64eb2b90776bb1e37de009208f016f176bd6a82a
Closes-Bug: #1762431

commit_message:
Add LIBVIRT_CPU_MODE configuration option

Some VMs may require to have the cpu_mode set to specific value:
- host, host-passthrough, ...
This patch adds the configuration option "LIBVIRT_CPU_MODE" to
be able to set the cpu_mode for nova/libvirt.
The default behavior ('cpu_mode=none') is not modified.

Change-Id: Id1ce9a308c51d0268a3d267d1eeedde63b8b6b71
Signed-off-by: Christophe Fontaine <christophe.fontaine@qosmos.com>

If I understand this correctly, I don't think this is a keystoneauth issue, but a python requests issue. See:

http://docs.python-requests.org/en/master/user/advanced/#ca-certificates
https://github.com/kennethreitz/requests/issues/2966

I don't think keystoneauth is the right place for this."}, {'account_id': 6522, 'date': '2017-04-05 13:44:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

I don't think it matters, if Keystone Auth is going to make use of Python Requests it needs to work within its boundaries of what is supported."}, {'account_id': 6522, 'date': '2017-04-05 13:45:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

Additionally, the way that KeystoneAuth currently makes use of Python Requests is broken when it comes to Verification of SSL Connections. And it needs to be fixed.

Even if (opionon* is) this isn't an optimal solution, it is a Solution and a Solution is better then leaving it broken."}, {'account_id': 17860, 'date': '2017-04-05 14:14:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

I agree with Colleen that *if* this is not an issue in keystoneclient and Python Requests is supposed to support that, we should report a bug against that lib and fix it there instead.

If we fix it in the source every single system that uses it will benefit, which is better than just working around it locally in our project. This is just how open source works.

However, if this is super critical, I'd be okay with accepting a bandaid fix while the bug is addressed in the source.

If the way keystoneauth use of requests is broken, let's fix it."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2017-04-05 14:16:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Verified+1

Build succeeded (check pipeline).

Finally, if keystoneauth goal is to mimic or match curl in features, then this is way to go about that.'}, {'account_id': 6522, 'date': '2017-04-05 14:26:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Right, which right now it is broken. Because of the way that keystone auth is being used by every Openstack Service not every service in every circumstance passes the "os-cacert" read from the configuration. 

This actually limits the need for "os-cacert" from being required under many circumstances as well. Which allows greater usability and flexibility with the interactions of other Openstack Services.

I don't agree that this is an issue with Requests. Requests should allow for flexibility in the way it is used, and KeystoneAuth should be able to make decisions on how to use Requests. Such as asserting which CA Bundle/Path to use.'}, {'account_id': 6522, 'date': '2017-04-05 14:27:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

** Previous post should read,

This fixes the need for "os-cacert" to be required under many circumstances.'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2017-04-05 15:15:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

I didn't mean to imply that I think this is a bug we should fix in the python requests library that can be temporarily band-aided. I meant that this is a long standing behavior of the library and OpenStack's way of handling it is to allow a cacert config option, and I think changing the current behavior shouldn't be taken lightly.

For what it is worth, I believe most distros add a patch to their requests packages to trust the system CA bundle, so users who install via distro packages rather than pip/source don't have this problem."}, {'account_id': 6522, 'date': '2017-04-05 15:43:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

Fair enough, the problem is that because of the scope and abundance use of this library the CACert option isn't adhered to 100%, this alleviates the need for a strict adherence to passing CACert since it is obviously not being followed 100% time now anyway"}, {'account_id': 6522, 'date': '2017-04-05 18:34:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

So rejecting this because you are rely'ing on the distro(s) to patch dependent libraries is probably a bad idea, imo."}, {'account_id': 7725, 'date': '2017-04-05 21:36:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

(4 comments)

It sounds like this is really a work around for some OpenStack project lacking --os-cert support. What would it take to fix those?

This reminds me of "In the face of ambiguity, refuse the temptation to guess." from The Zen of Python.'}, {'account_id': 6522, 'date': '2017-04-05 22:33:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

The default_get_verify_paths.openssl_* is the same as capath/cafile."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2017-04-06 14:39:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Verified-1

The standard CA file has _lots_ of strange CA's in it. Are we really saying that Keystone should allow SSL certificate for _any_ CA installed on the system?"}, {'account_id': 6522, 'date': '2017-04-13 17:13:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15:

So that is an opinionated statement, you are not any clarifying what you mean by strange.

Regardless, yes it is otherwise the responsibility of a System Administrator to ensure that their OpenSSL installation is on par with what CA(s) they deem trustable. Otherwise the default trust is being determined by the upstream distributor of the OpenSSL packages (i.e. Linux Distro, Mozilla, etc.).'}, {'account_id': 7063, 'date': '2017-04-13 17:39:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15: Code-Review-1

While it's certainly the responsibility of a system administrator to ensure that the CA bundles installed are their systems are appropriate, almost all rely on the default provided by their distributions. Most systems have at least two bundles, the distribution one and an NSS (Mozilla) bundle. The NSS bundle alone (https://hg.mozilla.org/mozilla-central/raw-file/tip/security/nss/lib/ckfw/builtins/certdata.txt) has hundreds of root CA's installed.

It is reasonable to assume that in the vast majority of deployments, the CA certificates installed on a system will be the default distro provided ones. That being the case, I think it is negligent for an OpenStack service that has a significant security enforcing role to fail-open and accept a certificate from any of these CAs, especially as in insecure test environments an option exists to explicitly disable SSL."}, {'account_id': 6522, 'date': '2017-04-13 18:04:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15:

That seems like a ridiculous statement, by default that's exactly what is being done now by Python Requests (as requests uses a bundled copy of mozillla's CA bundle). 

This changes from using Python Requests to the system Bundle so that the CA Bundle can be properly managed.  

Your concern on the number of CA(s) is why your default HTTPS Requests work, FYI!!"}, {'account_id': 7063, 'date': '2017-04-13 18:07:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15: -Code-Review

If that's the case then the commit message should probably reflect it. 

However, just because one library does something poorly doesn't mean you should copy it in alternative code. 

Removing the -1 because you've stated this isn't a degradation of security but it's pretty bad practice imho and a security service such as Keystone should be setting the bar higher. 

Probably a good candidate for an OSSN."}, {'account_id': 7063, 'date': '2017-04-13 18:14:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15:

> If that's the case then the commit message should probably reflect
 > it.
 > 
 > However, just because one library does something poorly doesn't
 > mean you should copy it in alternative code.
 > 
 > Removing the -1 because you've stated this isn't a degradation of
 > security but it's pretty bad practice imho and a security service
 > such as Keystone should be setting the bar higher.
 > 
 > Probably a good candidate for an OSSN.

I should have probably phrased my comment around removing the -1 better.

This seems like a missed opportunity to improve security. Whatever the library being used, I don't think it's reasonable for Keystone to accept the default installed CAs.

Does Keystone currently provide good documentation/guidance around this point? As I mentioned before it seems like a good issue to have an OSSN signpost for: "If you care about security here, you're probably going to want to limit the CA's that KeystoneAuth trusts, either through curating your CA bundles or by providing KeystoneAuth with an alternative bundle to trust altogether)'}, {'account_id': 6522, 'date': '2017-04-13 18:25:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15:

@Robert you can make comments on the release notes for this change.'}, {'account_id': 7063, 'date': '2017-04-13 22:09:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15:

I didn't realise this was client side, my mistake. I was trying to comment on this change without making sure I understood the context, I incorrectly interpreted this as being related to the Keystone service's token validation on the server side, where perhaps a more rigorous validation is required.

This is a reasonable thing to do client side, there's no discernable security impact from this change that I can see. 

Sorry for the confusion earlier."}, {'account_id': 6522, 'date': '2017-04-14 03:17:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 16.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2017-04-14 04:20:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16: Verified-1

- gate-keystoneauth-pep8-ubuntu-xenial http://logs.openstack.org/85/452585/17/check/gate-keystoneauth-pep8-ubuntu-xenial/a5c56d7/ : SUCCESS in 2m 07s

- gate-keystoneauth-releasenotes http://docs-draft.openstack.org/85/452585/17/check/gate-keystoneauth-releasenotes/37feb5d//releasenotes/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 1m 54s'}, {'account_id': 6522, 'date': '2017-05-09 23:01:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 7191, 'date': '2017-05-10 01:41:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 17: Code-Review-1

So this topic has come up so many times. 

Yes, it's dumb that requests doesn't look at the system cert bundles, but i'm really not sure about the impact of changing the defaults of the whole world. 

For most people this has been a long solved problem. All the automation stuff just inserts the correct ca bundle into the service config files, and for client side the included CAs have been reasonably good.

I'm not saying no, but this overrides fairly well known python logic and i would like way more community input than is going to be seen on the bug/review alone. 

Rope in at least monty, dean troyer and sean dague."}, {'account_id': 6522, 'date': '2017-05-10 02:47:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17:

I agree ideally it would be best to throw this back at requests or which ever library was handling this. But in lieu the current situation is quite messy (i.e. "requiring" a ca-cert in every call). This resolves that for almost all use cases.'}, {'account_id': 18108, 'date': '2017-05-10 15:05:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 17:

Hey folks, your friendly neighbourhood Requests maintainer dropping in.

I can't speak to whether it's sensible for Keystone to adopt this change *in general*: that's for y'all to decide what your priorities are. But I can give you some extra context about what Requests is doing and why we're doing it, and what some other options might be.

*In general*, Requests is not inclined to go searching all over the filesystem for the default certificate locations. There are a lot of reasons for that, which I can go into if people are interested, but the short version of this is that we're not inclined to do it. This is not a policy we're planning to change in the near future, though we have some long-term Python enhancements in the fire that may free us up to change our minds on this (including PEP 543).

However, we understand that it is a use-case that is important to a subset of our users, particularly the ones that we share with you (specifically, enterprises with robust solutions for managing trust bundles). As noted elsewhere in the chain, distribution-provided copies of Requests automatically trust their own trust bundles, so they do not have this issue: it affects only those installing Requests via pip. We are making longer-term moves to make it possible to generally use the system trust bundle, but until Requests gets a system that behaves well on macOS and Windows as well as on Unices we are unlikely to turn this on by default.

In this situation, our guidance has been to set the REQUESTS_CA_BUNDLE environment variable. This will override our use of certifi as our default trust store and will instead cause us to use whatever path is provided there. This is a reasonably low-friction way to get OS-native behaviour on Linux and BSDs. This is an alternative option for KeystoneAuth users which does not require a patch.

If that's not sufficient, I don't think this patch is appalling: I think it's taking advantage of assumptions we don't believe we can make in Requests. With some careful productisation it could be a reasonable solution."}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2018-05-16 16:25:56.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

This is fairly old at this point. Feel free to restore if it's still relevant."}]

commit_message:
KeystoneAuth should default to system CAFile.

When SSL Verfication is enabled (by default),
not specifying a default CABundle causes unexpected
SSL verification failures.

Change-Id: I62e5d58d5635b4541c8b65f83003c68f0b55c750
Closes-Bug: #1678686

I was thinking of this from like an enterprise managed DNS perspective. I realize you can't send '_openstack_keystone' as a replicated value across the whole DNS system. 

I don't know if there is much point in having records for public providers because you would still need to specify a hostname to resolve on which would be provided with credentials, and so you are simply exchanging OS_AUTH_URL for OS_AUTH_DNS or something."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-10-15 07:07:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Verified-1

commit_message:
Support DNS lookup for generic plugins

If no auth_url is provided to the generic plugins then the plugin should
be able to determine the root keystone URL from DNS and use that as its
entrypoint.

Implements: bp dns-discovery
Change-Id: Ia1ee07710d955d949909313ed51643f34097dbf7

Patch works fine for saml2.Password plugin. I tested it with shibboleth IdP (testshib.org).

Unfortunately things don't go that smooth when it comes to ADFS plugin. New code fails when sending assertion to https://service.provider/Shibbolth.sso/ADFS (so ADFS endpoint), whereas old one on the same setup works.

I suggest we either put it all on hold until we fix adfs issue or split this patch into two: dealing with saml2 ecp and another with adfs only code."}, {'account_id': 6486, 'date': '2015-11-12 15:21:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

I don't think it's worth it to split this in 2 since we'd still have the lxml requirement, and since I don't have the means to run the test myself maybe it's best to just abandon."}, {'account_id': 6486, 'date': '2015-11-12 15:22:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

unless we can develop a test that somehow recreates how the ADFS endpoint works.'}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2015-11-14 17:22:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review-1

I think we should develop a test to recreate how the ADFS endpoint works. I mean, we should do that regardless of whether we move from lxml or not, because the by-hand testing as shown that our in-tree coverage is not complete.

Once that test is in place, I think this is a great patch and would be sad for it to be abandoned.'}, {'account_id': 8978, 'date': '2015-11-16 09:47:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

Sure, don't abandon it. Maybe put on hold until we figure out what's going on. 

@Monty: the problem with ADFS is that is commercial product. While we have it at CERN I can test solution with my own credentials, others may not. There was some sort of mail loop between few of Keystoners (Morgan and myself included) and some people from MS but eventually we didn't get any consensus. However, I have other contacts at MS right now so I might try with them."}, {'account_id': 6486, 'date': '2015-11-16 19:33:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Workflow-1

commit_message:
Switch saml2 from lxml to built-in xml

The saml2 code didn't use any xpath that couldn't be worked around
pretty easily. Without the extra lxml requirement, this code doesn't
need to be optional.

Another difference is namespace support. While built-in XML allows
the application to register namespaces, it's done globally, which
would not be a friendly thing for a library to do. As such, the
namespacing is left up to the xml library.

The tests continue to use lxml as much as possible for now to show
that they're compatible.

Change-Id: I0716641f8fb28e8dbc261e3af91857b9c8e52b23

commit_message:
[adapter.py] Add application/json header

When using python-heatclient or python-openstackclient we are
facing an issue when we want to create a stack.

This is issue is due to a missing header in LegacyJsonAdapter class.

Closes-Bug: #1638451
Change-Id: I3c25ad87d2849df762f43ba00e308c2b720859b9

commit_message:
DNM: Test nova-api eventlet deprecation

This just tells devstack to run nova-api using eventlet
and we should then see the deprecation warnings in the
n-api logs in the nova-next job.

Change-Id: I295586f1b7391c4a9b97ef2896627d12d72b7fe0

commit_message:
Fix missed kolla_action and kolla_serial

In change I78cb60168aaa40bb6439198283546b7faf33917c, action was changed
to kolla_action, and serial to kolla_serial, to avoid Ansible warnings
due to use of reserved keywords. In that change, some keywords were
missed, and some changes that were merged since then have not switched
to the new variables. This change fixes all current instances of those
issues.

Change-Id: I357dffdfcb2b405e280a962d366ee65eebf0a8d1
Implements: blueprint migrate-to-ansible-2-2-0

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-15 11:51:20.000000000', 'message': 'Use "passive_deletes=True" in ORM relationships

* Using "passive_deletes=True" when configuring relationships
  with SQLAlchemy significantly reduces memory footprint when
  deleting a graph of objects (e.g. root workflow execution
  with all dependent tasks, actions and sub workflows) from DB.
  This happens because in this case SQLAlchemy doesn't load
  those dependent objects that are not yet in the session and
  rather relies on cascading mechanisms of databases which are
  activated by the proper configuration of foreign key columns.
  For example, "ON DELETE CASCADE" clause in the foreign key
  definition in case of for MySQL.
  Particularly, this change reduces memory footprint of API
  processes when deleting large graphs of executions and
  execution expiration policy mechanism where the same happens
  but on the engine side.
* Added a test to make sure that cascaded deletion works well
  with this new property.

Related-Bug: #1757966
Change-Id: I36988817fb8e7695094ef98958b8aa151208fadb

commit_message:
Use "passive_deletes=True" in ORM relationships

* Using "passive_deletes=True" when configuring relationships
  with SQLAlchemy significantly reduces memory footprint when
  deleting a graph of objects (e.g. root workflow execution
  with all dependent tasks, actions and sub workflows) from DB.
  This happens because in this case SQLAlchemy doesn't load
  those dependent objects that are not yet in the session and
  rather relies on cascading mechanisms of databases which are
  activated by the proper configuration of foreign key columns.
  For example, "ON DELETE CASCADE" clause in the foreign key
  definition in case of for MySQL.
  Particularly, this change reduces memory footprint of API
  processes when deleting large graphs of executions and
  execution expiration policy mechanism where the same happens
  but on the engine side.
* Added a test to make sure that cascaded deletion works well
  with this new property.

Related-Bug: #1757966
Change-Id: I36988817fb8e7695094ef98958b8aa151208fadb

'}, {'created': '2018-04-26 14:09:34.000000000', 'message': 'Enable config-download deployment tracking

With introduction of config-download the deployment process is split into 2 parts
and it can no more be tracked by tracking Heat stack creation. Deployment status
is now stored in Swift object and is updated by Mistral workflows. This allows
clients to easily retrieve the current deployment status at any point of time.

This change brings necessary changes to accomodate new deployment status/progress
tracking

* Disable all fetching related to heat stack from CurrentPlan
  and replace it with deployment status from swift
* Update DeployStep and DeploymentDetail to render Deployment status components by
  deploymentStatus
* Separate DeploymentConfirmation and DeploymentDetail into different routes
* Move deployment actions from PlansActions to separate DeploymentActions
* Update deployment status/progress by responding to Zaqar messages sent during
  the process
* Update deployment status components to use deploymentStatus rather than stack
  status
* Remove Heat stack polling to get deployment status

Change-Id: Ifd0f2a73310e53102a31991103aa8d0eeed203d5

commit_message:
Enable config-download deployment tracking

With introduction of config-download the deployment process is split
into 2 parts and it can no more be tracked by tracking Heat stack
creation. Deployment status is now stored in Swift object and is
updated by Mistral workflows. This allows clients to easily retrieve
the current deployment status at any point of time.

This change brings necessary changes to accomodate new deployment
status/progress tracking

* Disable all fetching related to heat stack from CurrentPlan
  and replace it with deployment status from swift
* Update DeployStep and DeploymentDetail to render Deployment status
  components by deploymentStatus
* Separate DeploymentConfirmation and DeploymentDetail into different
  routes
* Remove deployment actions from PlansActions and use
  DeploymentActions
* Update deployment status/progress by responding to Zaqar messages
  sent during the process
* Update deployment status components to use deploymentStatus rather
  than stack status
* Remove Heat stack polling to get deployment status

Implements: blueprint config-download-ui
Change-Id: Ifd0f2a73310e53102a31991103aa8d0eeed203d5

We could also use some tests here.'}, {'account_id': 7509, 'date': '2018-05-02 13:50:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 7509, 'date': '2018-05-02 15:54:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 20970, 'date': '2018-05-02 17:39:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11: Code-Review-1

When the deployment_status.yaml file can't be found in Swift, we cannot ignore the error, and dispatch the success function.  This masks the error, and wrongly sets the deployment as UNDEPLOYED.  The code works correctly when there is actual data coming from the server: if the payload is undefined, the Map() is empty, and the deployment status is set to the default of the DeploymentStatus record.  When the deployment_status.yaml file can't be found, we should set the status to UNKNOWN."}, {'account_id': 7509, 'date': '2018-05-03 08:21:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

> When the deployment_status.yaml file can't be found in Swift, we
 > cannot ignore the error, and dispatch the success function.  This
 > masks the error, and wrongly sets the deployment as UNDEPLOYED. 
 > The code works correctly when there is actual data coming from the
 > server: if the payload is undefined, the Map() is empty, and the
 > deployment status is set to the default of the DeploymentStatus
 > record.  When the deployment_status.yaml file can't be found, we
 > should set the status to UNKNOWN.

I agree, problem is that deployment_status.yaml is currently created when deploy_plan workflow is started. Until then, that object in swift does not exist. That's why non existence of the object is currently treated as UNDEPLOYED. (The error is not ignored, it is explicitly treated as a valid option which determines non deployed deployment)

To change this, we would have to update create_plan workflow to set deployment status and update delete_plan workflow to allow deleting plan only if deployment status is UNDEPLOYED and as part of it delete whole <deploymentPlanName>-messages swift container which stores deployment status as well as zaqar messages.

If you agree, how about doing these changes as part of subsequent patches which also introduce undeploy_plan workflow?"}, {'account_id': 10112, 'date': '2018-05-03 18:57:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 10112, 'date': '2018-05-03 20:21:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

I agree, let's follow-up with subsequent patches"}, {'account_id': 20970, 'date': '2018-05-04 13:11:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

> a valid option which determines non deployed deployment

I have demonstrated this to be false for certain deployments.

All I'm asking is that we make the UI more defensive when getting strange data from the server. This patch introduces a breaking change, and I'd like to provide a smoother transition.  If you're happy to break existing deployments, and to remove the possibility of removing said deployments by using the UI, then fine, let's leave it alone.

We're also still missing tests, and you haven't addressed the *UI naming scheme comment (it breaks away from existing patterns)."}, {'account_id': 7509, 'date': '2018-05-09 12:11:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 20970, 'date': '2018-05-09 12:52:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 26285, 'date': '2018-05-09 14:11:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 7509, 'date': '2018-05-11 13:56:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 13.'}, {'account_id': 7509, 'date': '2018-05-11 14:05:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

(1 comment)

I have added a set of tests. I thing it would be good to keep deployment status app state split into 2 reducers (deploymentStatusByPlan and deploymentStatusUI) as it nicely separates the user interface state and deployment status state. This makes reducers simpler. Both are tracked per deployment plan. We could even go one step further and separate configDownload messages into a separate reducer which would make CONFIG_DOWNLOAD_MESSAGE part of reducer even simpler as we could just set deployment status on GET_DEPLOYMENT_STATUS_SUCCESS instead of updating it due to keeping the configDownload messages around.'}, {'account_id': 10112, 'date': '2018-05-11 20:59:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 7509, 'date': '2018-05-14 13:33:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 14: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 8871, 'date': '2018-05-14 16:42:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14:

commit_message:
Add deployment status tracking infrastructure

This change is a first step of adding support for config-download,
it introduces actions, reducers, selectors and immutable records
to track deployment status

Implements: blueprint config-download-ui
Change-Id: I748f5151949327ace7f7d824cc5c29a00df0437a

commit_message:
Add ability to control Glance's enabled_import_methods

Add GlanceEnabledImportMethods parameter, and set the default value to
restrict Glance from using its 'glance-direct' import method. The
glance-direct method requires a special configuration when deployed in
an HA environment, and that capability will be added in a later release.

Closes-Bug: #1765439
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/568366
Change-Id: I7038601d7505a60df2a1fb7fd8db818efa105341

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-04-12 15:33:18.000000000', 'message': 'Allow setting client name on the Session

Sometimes, you have a library, such a shade, that creates one Session
and a bunch of adapters on top of that - but it's still the same client.
Allowing setting the client_name and client_version on the Session as
defaults avoids having to do it on every adapter/call.

Also, it turns out that without setting it on the Session, the
client_name/client_version doens't get passed to keystone discovery
calls (because they're done transparently on the Session) so the call to
the version discovery document incorrectly reports

  "User-Agent: v.py/1 os-client-config/1.26.1 keystoneauth1/2.18.0
               python-requests/2.13.0 CPython/2.7.12"

when it should report

  "User-Agent: v.py/1 os-client-config/1.26.1 shade/1.19.1
               keystoneauth1/2.18.0 python-requests/2.13.0 CPython/2.7.12"

like the rest of the calls.

Change-Id: Id83f8baa0e905b814326f079fde7bef5dd8177fc
'}]
commit_message:
Allow setting client name on the Session

Sometimes, you have a library, such a shade, that creates one Session
and a bunch of adapters on top of that - but it's still the same client.
Allowing setting the client_name and client_version on the Session as
defaults avoids having to do it on every adapter/call.

Also, it turns out that without setting it on the Session, the
client_name/client_version doens't get passed to keystone discovery
calls (because they're done transparently on the Session) so the call to
the version discovery document incorrectly reports

  "User-Agent: v.py/1 os-client-config/1.26.1 keystoneauth1/2.18.0
               python-requests/2.13.0 CPython/2.7.12"

when it should report

  "User-Agent: v.py/1 os-client-config/1.26.1 shade/1.19.1
               keystoneauth1/2.18.0 python-requests/2.13.0 CPython/2.7.12"

like the rest of the calls.

Change-Id: Id83f8baa0e905b814326f079fde7bef5dd8177fc

subject: Added new logger to log request_id
messages: [{'account_id': 20182, 'date': '2017-10-03 06:09:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 17860, 'date': '2017-10-05 13:16:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1\n\nThere is a patch for splitting this already, see https://review.openstack.org/#/c/505764/'}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2018-05-16 15:26:03.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2017-10-03 06:09:25.000000000', 'message': "Added new logger to log request_id

Created a new logger instance 'request_id_logger’ which will be
used to log 'X-Openstack-Request-Id' for each API call only
when ‘keystoneauth.request-ids’ logger is set with logging
level ‘INFO’ and below.

Example of log message:

INFO keystoneauth.request_ids [None req-74cc49de-4316-469f-8a05-62a9f7cc53bc admin admin]
GET call to network for
http://10.232.48.200:9696/v2.0/security-groups?id=da5604ea-5d65-4c1a-bb12-9ee8d9fe104e
used request id req-f82663b4-38ae-46ec-a76d-50748dd38895

To use this feature, user must add ‘keystoneauth.request_ids=INFO’
to ’default_log_levels' config option of individual OpenStack
service config file.
For example in nova.conf, ‘default_log_levels' should
be set as below:

default_log_levels = […, ‘keystoneauth.request_ids=INFO’]

Also, changed the logging level from ‘debug’ to ‘info’ as
operator now can decide whether to log  request_ids or not
using newly added logger name.

Change-Id: I78f5f0109728c083a4b559c00c7322bfa6b77fae
"}]
commit_message:
Added new logger to log request_id

Created a new logger instance 'request_id_logger’ which will be
used to log 'X-Openstack-Request-Id' for each API call only
when ‘keystoneauth.request-ids’ logger is set with logging
level ‘INFO’ and below.

Example of log message:

INFO keystoneauth.request_ids [None req-74cc49de-4316-469f-8a05-62a9f7cc53bc admin admin]
GET call to network for
http://10.232.48.200:9696/v2.0/security-groups?id=da5604ea-5d65-4c1a-bb12-9ee8d9fe104e
used request id req-f82663b4-38ae-46ec-a76d-50748dd38895

To use this feature, user must add ‘keystoneauth.request_ids=INFO’
to ’default_log_levels' config option of individual OpenStack
service config file.
For example in nova.conf, ‘default_log_levels' should
be set as below:

default_log_levels = […, ‘keystoneauth.request_ids=INFO’]

Also, changed the logging level from ‘debug’ to ‘info’ as
operator now can decide whether to log  request_ids or not
using newly added logger name.

Change-Id: I78f5f0109728c083a4b559c00c7322bfa6b77fae

subject: Implement ReqContextManager for Session
messages:
[{'account_id': 2, 'date': '2016-08-29 22:17:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 7191, 'date': '2016-08-29 22:58:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

Still going to think about this but comments on the review. 

1) What's the need for the result_filter_cb? Particularly for the session I'm not sure what you would be manipulating here by the time it comes back to a client. The clients should really work fine as they are. 

2) I'd like to see if we can do this without the self._client and just pass around a bound function. It's not always used, creates a circular reference and seems like the sort of thing that should be bound to a task rather than the whole manager."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-08-29 23:21:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified+1

Build succeeded (check pipeline).

- gate-keystoneauth-docs-ubuntu-xenial http://docs-draft.openstack.org/73/362473/1/check/gate-keystoneauth-docs-ubuntu-xenial/f48c60f//doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 2m 23s
- gate-keystoneauth-pep8-ubuntu-xenial http://logs.openstack.org/73/362473/1/check/gate-keystoneauth-pep8-ubuntu-xenial/fb3bee6/ : SUCCESS in 2m 19s
- gate-keystoneauth-python27-ubuntu-xenial http://logs.openstack.org/73/362473/1/check/gate-keystoneauth-python27-ubuntu-xenial/8d58be2/ : SUCCESS in 3m 00s
- gate-keystoneauth-python34 http://logs.openstack.org/73/362473/1/check/gate-keystoneauth-python34/af689d4/ : SUCCESS in 4m 07s
- gate-keystoneauth-python35-nv http://logs.openstack.org/73/362473/1/check/gate-keystoneauth-python35-nv/facb393/ : SUCCESS in 2m 55s (non-voting)
- gate-tempest-dsvm-neutron-src-keystoneauth http://logs.openstack.org/73/362473/1/check/gate-tempest-dsvm-neutron-src-keystoneauth/0c809a5/ : SUCCESS in 1h 03m 16s'}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2016-08-29 23:28:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)

Great questions.

1) results_filter_cb is a way to pass all results through a filter (wow, 'm helpful) Best example would be this: http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack-infra/shade/tree/shade/task_manager.py#n168  ... although that's not using the results_filter_cb interface ... it really should be.

2) self._client is bound to the TaskManager because it's the resource TaskManager is managing. A Task doesn't own the client ... because you can have a Task that's run by more than one TaskManager. (If you think of the purpose of TaskManager as controlling the execution of Tasks on a given resource, it might make more sense)  It looks especially weird in the ksa case because there are no pre-baked Task objects - just the auto-generated one - and the ksa Session is the only 'client'."}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2016-08-29 23:51:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2016-11-28 20:23:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2016-11-28 20:24:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

I have looked over the code and this all makes sense. The most recent patchset has included the shade unit tests for the task manager.

I am including my +2 here as the code has locally passed unit tests and the unit tests were almost 100% copy/paste.'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2016-11-28 20:26:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(3 comments)

I'm still not sure i'm convinced. 

When looking through shade the taskmanager is definitely designed to be outside the client view so you aren't rate limiting or threading (i don't see where threading is implemented?). 

From a keystoneauth perspective the bare minimum of what you need is a way to control things that are passing into and out of session.request() so why not a user controlled context manager, like:

with self.context_manager:
    return session.request(*args, **kwargs) 

we could find something better so that context manager had access to args/kwargs - but that's really all you actually want there right?"}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2016-11-30 02:53:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

I'll respin this as a ctx_manager interface shortly."}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2016-12-01 02:49:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2016-12-01 02:51:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2016-12-01 02:57:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2016-12-01 02:58:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review+2

revisions:
[{'created': '2016-08-29 22:17:27.000000000', 'message': "Import TaskManager from shade/nodepool

nodepool and shade use a concept of a TaskManager to execute remote
action. This allows for things like local rate limiting in a
multi-threaded TaskManager in nodepool, but a direct action passthrough
TaskManager in ansible.

Thing is, there are some actions, such as getting a new token that
happen behind the scenes. Also, some things, like openstacksdk and
glance list() operations, like to operate with generators rather than
network calls, meaning that the network calls the user desires to rate
limit are not actually in the user's control.

Add the code here to keystoneauth. It's very solid and in extremely
heavy use in nodepool, so it should change almost never. A follow up
patch will add it to Session so that all of the remote calls made by
Session will be encapsulated in TaskManager actions and therefore
transparently participate in any configured TaskManager.

Change-Id: I620f4e095228d4f0c6151ca70d030df86ae1b7c9
"}, {'created': '2016-11-28 20:23:27.000000000', 'message': "Import TaskManager from shade/nodepool

nodepool and shade use a concept of a TaskManager to execute remote
action. This allows for things like local rate limiting in a
multi-threaded TaskManager in nodepool, but a direct action passthrough
TaskManager in ansible.

Thing is, there are some actions, such as getting a new token that
happen behind the scenes. Also, some things, like openstacksdk and
glance list() operations, like to operate with generators rather than
network calls, meaning that the network calls the user desires to rate
limit are not actually in the user's control.

Add the code here to keystoneauth. It's very solid and in extremely
heavy use in nodepool, so it should change almost never. A follow up
patch will add it to Session so that all of the remote calls made by
Session will be encapsulated in TaskManager actions and therefore
transparently participate in any configured TaskManager.

The task manager unit tests from shade have also been directly
imported to ensure no regressions have occured in the import
of the TaskManager code itself. Further functional testing
will be implemented as the code continues to develop.

Change-Id: I620f4e095228d4f0c6151ca70d030df86ae1b7c9

"}, {'created': '2016-12-01 02:49:00.000000000', 'message': 'Implement TaskContextManager for Session

Nodepool and Shade use a concept of a task manager to execute remote
actions. This allows for things like local rate limiting in a multi-
threaded TaskManager in nodepool, but a direct action passthrough
TaskManager in Ansible.

This change implements a TaskContextManager that the keystoneauth
Session utilizes to make all requests. The default implementation
is one that behaves the same as if no specialized code is added.
Additional logic can be executed explicitly prior-to, during the
request handling, and post-request handling stages via the standard
context_manager style interfaces.

Session now always encapsulates the request via the TaskContextManager
or the class that acts the same passed to the Session constructor.

Change-Id: I620f4e095228d4f0c6151ca70d030df86ae1b7c9
Co-Authored-By: Monty Taylor <mordred@inaugust.com>

commit_message:
Implement ReqContextManager for Session

Nodepool and Shade use a concept of a task manager to execute remote
actions. This allows for things like local rate limiting in a multi-
threaded TaskManager in nodepool, but a direct action passthrough
TaskManager in Ansible.

This change implements a Request Context Manager that the keystoneauth
Session utilizes to make all requests. The default implementation
is one that behaves the same as if no specialized code is added.
Additional logic can be executed explicitly prior-to, during the
request handling, and post-request handling stages via the standard
context_manager style interfaces.

Session now always encapsulates the request via the ReqContextManager
or the class that acts the same passed to the Session constructor.

Change-Id: I620f4e095228d4f0c6151ca70d030df86ae1b7c9
Co-Authored-By: Monty Taylor <mordred@inaugust.com>

commit_message:
Nova: cell db name

Newton makes assumptions about the cell db name - this brings the
default values inline with that assumption.

Change-Id: I4cdbdb692e9b5c42c5bddf0050676cf6861cbecc

commit_message:
WIP: Ceph: Chart import from OSH

The ceph chart imported from its state as of commit,
sha:4399e39a9cd7b7b878aaf137cefd39a0dff81a06

The Delta between PS1 and the current PS show the changes required
to support:
 * RBAC - though this currently grants ceph a cluster-admin role
 * Local Image Repo Use
 * Multiple namespace support for service dependency checks

Change-Id: I85a04bb39fe02f302df0441c4bb9f6cf454c67f4

commit_message:
WIP: ZuulV3 compatible deployment and Kubeadm-aio2

This PS provides a replacement for the original gate scripts, using
ansible and compatible with ZuulV3 native operation. It also moves
kubeadm-aio to a more robust solution for deployment of clusters.

Change-Id: Ic036d6f718eb83d6830354f63b2d0a3b023cc605

commit_message:
Gate: Update CentOS and Fedora gates to use the LT Docker

This PS updates the gate script to use the current LT support version
of docker from the Distros repos. This has two effects:
1) moves to use docker 1.12.x inline with ubuntu
2) works round the tempory issue of k8s 1.7 defaulting to shared PID
namespaces with Docker >= 1.13 which causes issues for the rabbitmq
checks and also running systemd containers in pods.

Change-Id: I2e54733f7fd0e369f25b6dea5a5836bec754b036

commit_message:
Ceph: CephFS external provisioner and client helm tests

This PS adds CephFS support, proving a solution for charts requiring
`ReadWriteMany` PVs. It also adds `helm test` support for client
namespaces for both RBD and CephFS PV types.

Change-Id: Iaef890bcf651a1f963abbff82a63ffc49ff4e22c

commit_message:
RFC: Ingress VIP IP on edge nodes

This PS adds a VIP to edge nodes when running the ingress controller
in the Hosts Network NS. It is part of a larger effort to publish
services externally via ECMP IPs.

Please see: https://asciinema.org/a/bNnZS5Sc7iGjKKPOY7h7Emljq
And: https://openstack-lcoo.atlassian.net/browse/OSH-84

Change-Id: Ice3ec4865cd161da0464750ea4e0d8802d5a7c50

commit_message:
WIP: LOCI Image Support.

This PS provides LOCI image support. As LOCI images do not contain
any configuration once complete OpenStack-Helm should be entirely
image agnostic.

Change-Id: I62c738adaf3516cc3e12ff839a6c98c7525c0c26

commit_message:
Create Octavia policy roles and legacy admin-owner rules

Octavia has introduced new roles for more granular access policies.
This will create those keystone roles and if the legacy parameter
is set create admin or user rules which are similar what Neutron
allowed before.

Change-Id: I2d6b7278d7d4af2669cba7ac760dae0bc8e6f183

"}, {'created': '2018-05-16 13:50:28.000000000', 'message': 'fix doc build

Apparently pip 10 dropped the options for allowing external and
insecure packages. We shouldn't need those anyway.

Remove the index pages within each series directory, since the specs are
linked using a glob pattern in the main table of contents. This removes
all of the "$series Release" entries from the main table of contents.

Add the rocky directory specs to the master toctree

Change-Id: Ic8714c42f31a98020dfb70e65e9b2d9240fcf41b
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
'}]
commit_message:
fix doc build

Apparently pip 10 dropped the options for allowing external and
insecure packages. We shouldn't need those anyway.

Remove the index pages within each series directory, since the specs are
linked using a glob pattern in the main table of contents. This removes
all of the "$series Release" entries from the main table of contents.

Add the rocky directory specs to the master toctree

Change-Id: Ic8714c42f31a98020dfb70e65e9b2d9240fcf41b
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Allow having placement inventories with reserved value equal to total

Currently, we delete ironic node resource provider inventory from placement
to indicate that the node is not available for deployment during the cleaning
process or when in maintenance. This is not actually required as we can
reserve all the inventory, which describes more accurately what is going on,
and introduces issues like https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1771577.

APIImpact
blueprint: allow-reserved-equal-total-inventory
Change-Id: I0aec5e9f0a26430a9b104159c62ba1d07944ce9f

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-23 17:26:48.000000000', 'message': 'Create DNS records when using DNS HA

Deficiencies in the older maas API client that is used to manage
DNS records for DNS HA prevent DNS records being created. This
change creates the DNS records by directly interacting with the REST
maas api (v2). If the old approach of pre-creating the DNS records is
followed then those are used rather than creating new ones.

Change-Id: I6e1d7e5f0a7d813c78dfc1e78743ae7b218fbd01
Closes-Bug: 1764832
'}]
commit_message:
Create DNS records when using DNS HA

Deficiencies in the older maas API client that is used to manage
DNS records for DNS HA prevent DNS records being created. This
change creates the DNS records by directly interacting with the REST
maas api (v2). If the old approach of pre-creating the DNS records is
followed then those are used rather than creating new ones.

Change-Id: I6e1d7e5f0a7d813c78dfc1e78743ae7b218fbd01
Closes-Bug: 1764832

commit_message:
We don't need utils.trycmd any more.

Its only used in one place, let's just call processutils
directly instead.

Change-Id: Iff03a1b6889133ca938190a49fbf0b6b18b31c96
blueprint: hurrah-for-privsep

Build succeeded.

- nova-dsvm-full-tempest http://cloudbase-ci.com/nova/554437/20/ : SUCCESS in 2h 58m 31s'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2018-05-15 22:19:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 20: Code-Review-1

I think we need to hold up on this and investigate the nova-lvm failure more.

Doing a gerrit query and checking the most recent nova-lvm runs, none of them are failing, so I think there's a fair chance this is breaking lvm somehow:

https://review.openstack.org/#/q/project:openstack/nova+comment:experimental"}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-05-15 22:37:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 20: -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2018-05-15 22:45:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 20:

I'm currently running the nova-lvm job on an unrelated "add nova-slow job" patch to see if it will pass:

https://review.openstack.org/567697

Now, looking at the logs, if you take an example like /dev/stack-volumes-default/55acd916-99ed-49e5-9b4c-6f8e966e2c75_disk and search for it in the nova-lvm n-cpu log, you can see the 'qemu-img convert' privsep'd call on it earlier on:

"qemu-img convert -t none -O raw /opt/stack/data/nova/instances/_base/946d78b7df1c58bef1f96e3ff5cf25cfd11a7b96 /dev/stack-volumes-default/55acd916-99ed-49e5-9b4c-6f8e966e2c75_disk"

http://logs.openstack.org/37/554437/20/experimental/nova-lvm/fe95b28/logs/screen-n-cpu.txt.gz?#_May_15_14_54_27_415824

but then later when 'qemu-img info' runs with the same target, it fails with "Permission denied":

u"qemu-img: Could not open '/dev/stack-volumes-default/55acd916-99ed-49e5-9b4c-6f8e966e2c75_disk': Could not open '/dev/stack-volumes-default/55acd916-99ed-49e5-9b4c-6f8e966e2c75_disk': Permission denied\n"

http://logs.openstack.org/37/554437/20/experimental/nova-lvm/fe95b28/logs/screen-n-cpu.txt.gz?#_May_15_14_55_03_489199

On the surface, it seems like if 'qemu-img convert' ran as root, then 'qemu-img info' would need to run as root too in order to read the disk file ... so I don't get how this used to work prior to this change. I don't yet see how this change could result in a change in behavior there.'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2018-05-15 22:48:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 20:

Elaborating more, other commands that run on the example "/dev/stack-volumes-default/55acd916-99ed-49e5-9b4c-6f8e966e2c75_disk" also run with privsep, so they succeed. Whereas 'qemu-img info' does _not_ run with privsep, and it fails with "Permission denied".'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2018-05-16 03:00:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 20: Code-Review+2

Welp, looks like I was wrong. The nova-lvm job is currently failing on a completely unrelated patch, with the same error as seen here:

http://logs.openstack.org/97/567697/1/experimental/nova-lvm/2de28e7/logs/screen-n-cpu.txt.gz?level=TRACE

So, I guess we are good to go with this, and we need to track down what broke the nova-lvm job within the past ~4 days since it was last passing.'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2018-05-16 03:04:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 20:

I'm going to guess the nova-lvm job failure is related to this change:

https://review.openstack.org/567899"}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-05-16 12:52:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 20: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

Okay, let's go."}]

Move image conversion to privsep.

Following a similar pattern to previous changes, move calls to
qemu-img to convert between image formats to use privsep.

[{'created': '2018-05-15 12:34:35.000000000', 'message': 'Fix maintenance order unitests

The tests: test_get_deleted_resources_order and
test_get_inconsistent_resources_order were failing because the setUp()
method from its class was being invoked before the
SecurityGroupTestPlugin() was initialized.

That wasn't a problem before, but due to the commit
0c112a9f8997472bc9bc27b11501fc18c2e35dd5 in Neutron the "description"
field from the security groups API was removed in favor of the
standardattrdescription extension, therefor we needed that plugin to be
initialized before.

All this patch does is to move the setUp() call to after the plugins
initialization and it should do the trick (-:

Closes-Bug: #1771336
Change-Id: Ia7cba29861bfd3991c81e4af36d8abcf29cac159
'}, {'created': '2018-05-16 09:57:11.000000000', 'message': 'Fix gate problems: Unittest and CentOS new kernel

This patch is fixing two problems that are currently blocking the gate:

1. Unittests failure

The tests: test_get_deleted_resources_order and
test_get_inconsistent_resources_order were failing because the setUp()
method from its class was being invoked before the
SecurityGroupTestPlugin() was initialized.

That wasn't a problem before, but due to the commit
0c112a9f8997472bc9bc27b11501fc18c2e35dd5 in Neutron the "description"
field from the security groups API was removed in favor of the
standardattrdescription extension, therefor we needed that plugin to be
initialized before.

2. CentOS 7 new kernel version

There's some issue with the new kernel version (3.10.0-862) from CentOS7
which is causing the jobs to fail with an SSH timeout. The problem is
currently on investigation.

For now, let's switch the tempest-ovs-stable job back to ubuntu and
unblock the gate.

Closes-Bug: #1771336
Change-Id: Ia7cba29861bfd3991c81e4af36d8abcf29cac159
'}]
commit_message:
Fix gate problems: Unittest and CentOS new kernel

This patch is fixing two problems that are currently blocking the gate:

1. Unittests failure

The tests: test_get_deleted_resources_order and
test_get_inconsistent_resources_order were failing because the setUp()
method from its class was being invoked before the
SecurityGroupTestPlugin() was initialized.

That wasn't a problem before, but due to the commit
0c112a9f8997472bc9bc27b11501fc18c2e35dd5 in Neutron the "description"
field from the security groups API was removed in favor of the
standardattrdescription extension, therefor we needed that plugin to be
initialized before.

2. CentOS 7 new kernel version

There's some issue with the new kernel version (3.10.0-862) from CentOS7
which is causing the jobs to fail with an SSH timeout. The problem is
currently on investigation.

For now, let's switch the tempest-ovs-stable job back to ubuntu and
unblock the gate.

Closes-Bug: #1771336
Change-Id: Ia7cba29861bfd3991c81e4af36d8abcf29cac159

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-10 14:23:30.000000000', 'message': "Improve DbListCommand operation from O(n^2) to O(n)

Right now the DbListCommand retrieves the uuid's of all the elements
passed in as argument. This is an O(n^2) operation so when the number
of elements in a grows it's likely that we get Timeout Exceptions.

Instead of doing this, whenever possible, we'll retrieve all the
elements (from the in-memory replica) and only fetch those who were
passed as arguments avoiding the O(n^2) operation.

NOTE: this cherry pick conflicted because in stable/pike, the commands.py
file was in different location.

Closes-Bug: #1769897
(cherry picked from fd64d41ea6f208a5752fbcd45952a04633ee1392)
Signed-off-by: Daniel Alvarez <dalvarez@redhat.com>

Change-Id: Iacded885bb852315263ee926b9af5a1c3dc0dbba

commit_message:
Improve DbListCommand operation from O(n^2) to O(n)

Right now the DbListCommand retrieves the uuid's of all the elements
passed in as argument. This is an O(n^2) operation so when the number
of elements in a grows it's likely that we get Timeout Exceptions.

Instead of doing this, whenever possible, we'll retrieve all the
elements (from the in-memory replica) and only fetch those who were
passed as arguments avoiding the O(n^2) operation.

NOTE: this cherry pick conflicted because in stable/pike, the commands.py
file was in different location.

Closes-Bug: #1769897
(cherry picked from fd64d41ea6f208a5752fbcd45952a04633ee1392)
Signed-off-by: Daniel Alvarez <dalvarez@redhat.com>

Change-Id: Iacded885bb852315263ee926b9af5a1c3dc0dbba

commit_message:
Rescue bug: tinyipa fails to acquire IP in multitenant env

It seems the udhcpc script is not executable and no sleeping
cause tinyipa fails to acquire IP in multi-tenant env.

Story: #2002024
Change-Id: I3a693d75bfa54fe905bd3cd0587bb139934c087c

[{'created': '2018-05-14 12:04:02.000000000', 'message': 'build: remove info that image squash support is disabled

We do not tell that optionX or optionY is disabled so why we have to
inform that image squash is disabled?

This is an option which has to be enabled and then informing that it is

'}]
commit_message:
build: remove info that image squash support is disabled

We do not tell that optionX or optionY is disabled so why we have to
inform that image squash is disabled?

This is an option which has to be enabled and then informing that it is
enabled has sense.

Change-Id: I14b9b02e3cb290128d9f7673df8efe61aaa08c31

commit_message:
remove redundant index pages

Remove the index pages within each series directory, since the specs are
linked using a glob pattern in the main table of contents. This removes
all of the "$series Release" entries from the main table of contents.

Change-Id: I556990355c943a0bf86b09dcd3b0a1537a1b195a
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Updated undercloud tempest skip list for Pike

* tempest.api.identity.v2.test_tenants.IdentityTenantsTest.
  test_list_tenants_returns_only_authorized_tenants and
  tempest.api.identity.v2.test_users.IdentityUsersTest.
  test_user_update_own_password are failing due to
  admin_required permission issue. We will adding to skip list
  in order to pass the CI.

Change-Id: Id91e27b0d7bc399ed6dfdcc622ef523e4c96f55b

commit_message:
Throw an error on missing support for default microversion

We've given the user the ability to set a default microversion. However,
that microversion might not be available on the cloud in question. Throw
an error in such cases.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/568640
Change-Id: Ic600727a02fd3ba83e51a6a38ac784818c649c9b

commit_message:
Use openstack.config for arguments parsing

This change switches the CLI to use openstacksdk for populating
authentication arguments and creating a session. As a side effect,
using clouds.yaml is now supported and used in the CI.

Change-Id: If20ddc46f10d9deb34e595310313bd87e2e7243b
